newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean 3-yr yields end up on heavy new issues.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean 3-yr yields end up on heavy new issues.

text.p: Yields on three-year corporate bonds ended higher on Monday in depressed trading due to fears of more new issues next month, brokers said.
"New issues are estimated at more than 3.1 trillion won in November, compared with 2.8 trillion in October. The prospects dampened sentiment," said Lee Chang-woo, a broker at Samsung Securities.
Three-month CD yields ended flat as banks, leading CD traders, concentrated on meeting the central bank's review of their reserve status.
The overnight call rate also ended unchanged at 14.00 in the absence of fresh money demand in the shorter-term money market.
New three-year corporate issues were estimated at 66 billion won on Wednesday compared with 35 billion today.
Brokers said three-year yields could test the 12.15 level on Wednesday.
"There seems to be no boosting factors," said Park Ho-won, a broker at LG Securities.
